comment.author: 8944614@N02
comment._content: This is not exactly correct. The poster says (in my awkward translation), "Let's speed up industrialization in the USSR with deposits to the Labor Savings Offices." It urges workers to deposit their earnings to "сберегательные кассы" (State Labor Savings Offices; something like German Sparkasse), and the things being produced are not leaflets, but "сберегательные книжки" that is, savings books. Also, it is definitely not "circa 1920." First savings offices in the USSR were opened in 1923; industrialization had not started in earnest until the late 1920's; and the very style of the poster also points to the late 1920's–early 1930's.

comment.author: 35128489@N07
comment._content: Thanks Saumacus, this is really helpful! I’ve amended the date and description to reflect the information you’ve provided. The caption makes much more sense now, in that it’s actually asking people to do something, that than just making a statement. We’d always believed this and our other Soviet posters were collected by the British Labour Delegation to Russia in 1920, but it looks like this one at least is significantly later in date.
